PreFair: Privately Generating Justifiably Fair Synthetic Data

David Pujol Duke University dpujol@cs.duke.edu ,Â  Amir Gilad Duke University agilad@cs.duke.edu Â andÂ  Ashwin Machanavajjhala Duke University ashwin@cs.duke.edu
Abstract.

When a database is protected by Differential Privacy (DP), its usability is limited in scope. In this scenario, generating a synthetic version of the data that mimics the properties of the private data allows users to perform any operation on the synthetic data, while maintaining the privacy of the original data. Therefore, multiple works have been devoted to devising systems for DP synthetic data generation. However, such systems may preserve or even magnify properties of the data that make it unfair, rendering the synthetic data unfit for use. In this work, we present PreFair, a system that allows for DP fair synthetic data generation. PreFairÂ extends the state-of-the-art DP data generation mechanisms by incorporating a causal fairness criterion that ensures fair synthetic data. We adapt the notion of justifiable fairness to fit the synthetic data generation scenario. We further study the problem of generating DP fair synthetic data, showing its intractability and designing algorithms that are optimal under certain assumptions. We also provide an extensive experimental evaluation, showing that PreFairÂ generates synthetic data that is significantly fairer than the data generated by leading DP data generation mechanisms, while remaining faithful to the private data.

1. Introduction

Among the various privacy definitions that have been explored, Differential Privacy (DP) (Dwork, 2006) has emerged as the most reliable. DP allows users to get answers to queries and even train Machine Learning models over private data by augmenting the true answers with noise that cloaks information about individuals in the data. Indeed, multiple works have focused on answering queries over private data (Li and Miklau, 2013; Hardt etÂ al., [n.d.]; Hardt and Rothblum, 2010; McKenna etÂ al., 2018; Kotsogiannis etÂ al., 2019) and training models over such data (Abadi etÂ al., 2016; Papernot etÂ al., 2017). However, performing queries or training models directly on the private data has several prominent drawbacks. First, the class of allowed operations is limited. For example, only aggregate queries and specific techniques of training are allowed. Second, the data itself cannot be shared or used to explain the results and verify them without spending more precious privacy budget.

These limitations and others have driven the approach of generating synthetic data under DP (Chen etÂ al., 2020; Liu etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2014; AydÃ¶re etÂ al., 2021; Ge etÂ al., 2021; Jordon etÂ al., 2019; Hardt etÂ al., [n.d.]; Zhang etÂ al., 2021; Snoke and Slavkovic, 2018; Torkzadehmahani etÂ al., 2019; Rosenblatt etÂ al., 2020; Xie etÂ al., 2018; McKenna etÂ al., 2019, 2021). In general, these systems often work in two main steps as depicted in FigureÂ 1. First, they measure some set of summary statistics and generate some model to represent the data that is consistent with the measured statistics. This step is done in a privacy preserving manner by infusing noise into both the statistics and the model generating step. From that point, the synthetic data is sampled directly from the model in a non-private manner. DP synthetic data provides a strong formal guarantee of privacy on the original private data while creating a synthetic dataset that retains many of the properties of the original dataset. The synthetic data may then be used in any way and shared without additional privacy risk, due to the post-processing property of DP (Dwork and Roth, 2014).

However, as indicated by (Ganev etÂ al., 2022), the synthetic data generation process may preserve or even exacerbate properties in the data that make it unfair. There has been a significant effort in recent years to both define fairness (Kilbertus etÂ al., 2017; Salimi etÂ al., 2019; Kusner etÂ al., 2017; Verma and Rubin, 2018; Chouldechova, 2017; Corbett-Davies etÂ al., 2017; Dwork etÂ al., 2012; Berk etÂ al., 2021; Galhotra etÂ al., 2017; Kleinberg etÂ al., 2017; Nabi and Shpitser, 2018), and develop frameworks to understand and mitigate bias (Selbst etÂ al., 2019; Suresh and Guttag, 2021; Feldman etÂ al., 2015). Among these, causal approaches for fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019; Kusner etÂ al., 2017; Kilbertus etÂ al., 2017) propose a principled approach of measuring the effect of protected attributes on the outcome attributes. These works consider the causal relationship between protected attributes, i.e., those that cannot be explicitly used in decision making, admissible attributes, i.e., those that can be explicitly used in decision making, and outcome attributes that are the prediction targets.

Prior works have proposed frameworks for pre-processing steps to repair the data and ensure causal fairness (Feldman etÂ al., 2015; Calmon etÂ al., 2017; Salimi etÂ al., 2019). Notably, none of these have done so while under the constraint of DP as they assume the data is accessible.

In this paper, we propose PreFairÂ (Private and Fair synthetic data generation), a novel framework for generating fair synthetic data that satisfies DP. Our solution combines the state-of-the-art DP synthetic data generation system, MSTÂ (McKenna etÂ al., 2021) (shown to be the best performing mechanism in terms of minimizing the discrepancy between the private database and the generated one (Tao etÂ al., 2021)) with the robust causal fairness definition of Justifiable Fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019) to generate data that ensures fairness while satisfying DP. In justifiable fairness, the data is defined to be fair if there is no directed path in the causal graph between the protected attribute and the outcome attribute that does not pass through an admissible attribute in a graphical model which describes the data. Specifically, PreFairÂ augments the first step shown in FigureÂ 1 to satisfy the graph properties needed for Justifiable Fairness and provides a guarantee that the data generated in the second step will be fair, under a common assumption.

Example 1.

Consider the Adult dataset (Bache and Lichman, 2013) with the attributes age, marital-status (marital), education (edu), sex, income, and relationship. The MST system first learns the 2-way attribute marginals and then samples from them to generate a synthetic database instance.

FigureÂ 2(a) shows the graphical representation of the database attributes, generated by MST. Here, protected attributes are denoted with a subscript Î Î \Pi (and are colored red), admissible attributes are denoted with a subscript Î±ğ›¼\alpha (and are colored blue) and the outcome attribute with a subscript Î©Î©\Omega (and is colored green). The edges denote attributes that have a strong correlation between them in the private database. Note that the protected attribute sex (denoted by a subscript Î Î \Pi and colored red) has an edge to the income attribute which is the outcome. Intuitively, any synthetic database that will follow the distribution defined by this graph will have a direct dependence between the attribute sex and the attribute income, resulting in unfair data (while the graphical model is not a causal graph, we rely on the graphical properties of justifiable fairness). On the other hand, FigureÂ 2(b) shows an alternative graphical representation of the dependencies, generated by PreFair. In this graph, the path from sex to income passes through the admissible attribute education (the dashed edges colored blue). Intuitively, in any synthetic data that will adhere to this distribution, the influence of the sex attribute on income will be mitigated by the education attribute, which is considered admissible, so, it is allowed to directly influence the outcome.

Ensuring that PreFairÂ is useful gives rise to several challenges. In particular, we tackle the following challenges: (1) adapting the definition of fairness to undirected graphical models, (2) making a connection between the graphical model and the data to guarantee that a fair model would lead to the generation of fair data, and (3) providing efficient algorithms that will generate fair data while remaining faithful to the private data and satisfying DP.

Our contributions.

  • â€¢

    We propose PreFair, the first framework, to our knowledge, that generates synthetic data that is guaranteed to be fair and differentially private. PreFairÂ combines the state-of-the-art synthetic data generation approach that satisfies DP (McKenna etÂ al., 2021) with the definition of justifiable fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019).

  • â€¢

    We provide a novel model for fair data generation that relies on probabilistic graphical models and characterize the desiderata for the sampling approach to generate justifiably fair data.

  • â€¢

    We prove that finding the optimal fair graph in our model is NP-hard even in the absence of privacy.

  • â€¢

    Due to the intractability of the problem, we devise two solutions: (1) an algorithm that provides an optimal solution for an asymptotically large privacy budget and (2) a greedy algorithm that uses heuristics to construct the graph, while still guaranteeing fairness but possibly reducing the faithfulness to the private data.

  • â€¢

    We perform an extensive experimental evaluation to test PreFairÂ and show that our greedy approach can generate fair data while preserving DP and remaining faithful to the private data. We further show that our greedy approach does not incur major overhead in terms of performance.

2.1. Renyi Differential Privacy

In this paper, we employ the notion of Renyi-DP (RDP) (Mironov, 2017). This is a formal model of privacy that guarantees each individual that any query computed from sensitive data would have been almost as likely as if the individual had opted out. More formally, RDP is a property of a randomized algorithm that bounds the Renyi Divergence of output distributions induced by changes in a single record. To define privacy, we begin with neighboring databases.

Definition 0 (Neighboring Databases).

Two databases Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} are considered neighboring databases if Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} differ in at most one row. We denote this relationship by Dâ€²â‰ˆDsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ·D^{\prime}\approx D.

We often use the notion of neighboring databases to distinguish the impact of any particular individualâ€™s input on the output of a function. We likewise measure the maximum change in any function due to the removal or addition of one row often calling it the sensitivity of the function.

Definition 0 (Sensitivity).

Given a function fğ‘“f the sensitivity of fğ‘“f is sâ€‹uâ€‹pDâ€²â‰ˆDâ€‹|fâ€‹(D)âˆ’fâ€‹(Dâ€²)|ğ‘ ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘superscriptğ·â€²ğ·ğ‘“ğ·ğ‘“superscriptğ·â€²sup_{D^{\prime}\approx D}{|f(D)-f(D^{\prime})|} and is denoted by Î”â€‹fÎ”ğ‘“\Delta f.

From here we can define our formal notion of Privacy, RDP.

Definition 0 (Renyi Differential Privacy).

A randomized mechanism â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} satisfies (Î±,Î³)ğ›¼ğ›¾(\alpha,\gamma)-RDP for Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1 and Î³â‰¥0ğ›¾0\gamma\geq 0 if for any two neighboring databases Dğ·D, and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}:

where DÎ±(â‹…âˆ¥â‹…)D_{\alpha}(\cdot\|\cdot) is the Renyi divergence of order Î±ğ›¼\alpha between two probability distributions.

This ensures that no single individual contributes too much to the final output of the randomized algorithm by bounding the difference of the distributions when computed on neighboring databases.

All mechanisms that satisfy RDP also satisfy classic differential privacy (Dwork, 2006). Given privacy parameters Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î³ğ›¾\gamma the RDP guarantee can be translated into a classical DP guarantee as follows.

Theorem 4 (RDP to DP (Mironov, 2017)).

If a mechanism â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} satisfies (Î±,Î³)ğ›¼ğ›¾(\alpha,\gamma)-RDP it also satisfies (Î³+logâ¡(1/Î´)Î±âˆ’1,Î´)ğ›¾1ğ›¿ğ›¼1ğ›¿\left(\gamma+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\alpha-1},\delta\right) - DP for all Î´âˆˆ(0,1]ğ›¿01\delta\in(0,1].

The parameter Î³ğ›¾\gamma quantifies the privacy loss. While classic DP bounds the worst-case privacy loss, RDP treats privacy loss as a random variable which allows for computing a tighter bound over privacy loss in many situations. Our mechanisms, such as Algorithm 1 (SectionÂ 4.1), use repeated calls to the Gaussian mechanism and benefit from this tighter analysis. If there are two RDP releases of the same data with two different privacy parameters the amount of privacy loss is equivalent to the sum of their privacy parameters.

Theorem 5 (RDP composition (Mironov, 2017)).

Let â„³1subscriptâ„³1{\mathcal{M}}_{1} be an (Î±,Î³1)ğ›¼subscriptğ›¾1(\alpha,\gamma_{1})-RDP algorithm and â„³2subscriptâ„³2{\mathcal{M}}_{2} be an (Î±,Î³1)ğ›¼subscriptğ›¾1(\alpha,\gamma_{1})-differentially private algorithm. When designing private systems, designers are required to balance utility and privacy loss over several mechanisms to ensure that a global privacy loss is not exceeded. RDP is robust to post-processing, i.e., if any computation is done on an RDP data release without access to the original data, the additional computation also satisfies RDP.

The Gaussian mechanism (Mironov, 2017). This is a DP primitive for answering numerical queries and is often used to construct more complex DP mechanisms.

Both the Gaussian and Exponential mechanism are DP primitives which are often used as subroutines in the design of more complex DP mechanisms.

2.2. Marginals-MST

Previous work (McKenna etÂ al., 2021) has proposed an approach of using a Marginals-MSTÂ for generating DP synthetic data. The Marginals-MSTÂ is based on a Bayes network that encodes the 2-way marginals between the different attributes of the database. This approach was shown to be the state-of-the-art DP mechanism for generating synthetic data (Tao etÂ al., 2021). In the selection step (recall FigureÂ 1), the system generates a Marginals-MSTÂ which maximizes the pairwise mutual information over the attributes of the database. The mutual information between two attributes measures the mutual dependence between the two attributes. Two attributes that depend on each other more have higher mutual information. As such the 2-way marginals of attributes with high dependence on one another are chosen to be measured directly. Mutual information is defined as follows.

Definition 0 (Mutual Information (Cover and Thomas, 2005)).

The mutual information between two attributes Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} and Ajsubscriptğ´ğ‘—A_{j} is defined as follows.

(1) âˆ‘aiâˆˆdâ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹(Ai)âˆ‘ajâˆˆdâ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹(Aj)Pâ€‹[Ai=ai,Aj=aj]â€‹logâ¡(Pâ€‹[Ai=ai,Aj=aj]Pâ€‹[Ai=ai]â€‹Pâ€‹[Aj=aj])subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘šsubscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘šsubscriptğ´ğ‘—ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ´ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ´ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]subscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]subscriptğ´ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\sum_{a_{i}\in\\ dom(A_{i})}\quad\quad\sum_{\mathclap{a_{j}\in\\ dom(A_{j})}}P[A_{i}=a_{i},A_{j}=a_{j}]\log\left(\frac{P[A_{i}=a_{i},A_{j}=a_{j}]}{P[A_{i}=a_{i}]P[A_{j}=a_{j}]}\right)

Selection step. The Marginals-MSTÂ selection step is a three step process each with its own split of the privacy parameter. First, it measures the 1-way marginals. It then selects a set of 2-way marginals to measure by creating a graph where the nodes represent the attributes and the edges represent 2-way marginals between attributes. The weights of each edge are set to (an estimation of) the mutual information between the two attributes. It then uses a private mechanism to generate a maximum spanning tree (Marginals-MST) over this graph by using a private version of Kruskalâ€™s algorithm (Kruskal, 1956) where the exponential mechanism is used to select edges.

Definition 0 (Marginals-MST).

Given a database Dğ·D over the attribute set ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} and an undirected graph G=(V,E,w)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘¤G=(V,E,w), where V=ğ’œğ‘‰ğ’œV={\mathcal{A}}, Eğ¸E are edges between attributes, and w:VÃ—Vâ†’â„+:ğ‘¤â†’ğ‘‰ğ‘‰superscriptâ„w:V\times V\to\mathbb{R}^{+} returns the mutual information between every pair of attributes such that (A1,A2)âˆ‰Esubscriptğ´1subscriptğ´2ğ¸(A_{1},A_{2})\not\in E iff wâ€‹(A1,A2)=0ğ‘¤subscriptğ´1subscriptğ´20w(A_{1},A_{2})=0, a Marginals-MSTÂ is a spanning tree of GğºG.

Once the marginals are selected the final graphical model is constructed using Private PGM (McKenna etÂ al., 2019) which (approximately) preserves the conditional independence properties of the Marginals-MSTÂ as well as its marginals. From here the model is sampled directly.

Sampling step. Once the graphical model is generated, the data is sampled in a way similar to sampling from a Bayes net. It samples attributes one at a time with probabilities dependent on its already sampled neighbors. This imposes a direction in all the edges in the Marginals-MSTÂ resulting in a probability distribution that can be encoded in a directed Bayes net. The direction of the edges is directly dependent on the order in which the attributes are sampled with edges going from nodes which were sampled first toward nodes which were sampled later.

Example 2.

FigureÂ 3 shows the process of sampling from the Marginals-MSTÂ shown in FigureÂ 2(b). The first attribute to be sampled is age. Its probability is dependent only on its 1-way marginal probability. Then, marital-status is sampled. Since age is already sampled, marital-status is then sampled according to the estimated 2-way marginal distribution. This process continues down the tree until all attributes are sampled.

Likewise, this ensures that the final distribution (approximately) follows the local Markov property of Bayesian networks.

Definition 0 (Local Markov Property).

A graphical model ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} satisfies the Local Markov Property if each attribute is conditionally independent of its non-descendants given its parent values. This is formulated as follows.

A sufficient criteria to denote conditional independence is d-separation (Pearl, 2009) a condition that can be checked directly on the graph structure. We say that if ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} is a graphical model and Pâ€‹rğ‘ƒğ‘ŸPr is a probability distribution then Pâ€‹rğ‘ƒğ‘ŸPr is Markov compatible with ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} if a d-separation in ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} implies conditional independence in Pâ€‹rğ‘ƒğ‘ŸPr. or more formally.

If the converse is true, we say that Pâ€‹rğ‘ƒğ‘ŸPr is faithful to ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}}. In terms of Bayesian networks, the following is true.

Theorem 11.

If ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} is a directed acyclic graph over attributes ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} and Pâ€‹rğ‘ƒğ‘ŸPr is a probability distribution that follows EquationÂ 3, then Pâ€‹rğ‘ƒğ‘ŸPr is Markov compatible with ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}}.

Interventions on a Bayseian network are achieved via the do operator denoted doâ€‹(X=x)doğ‘‹ğ‘¥\text{do}(X=x). On the graph structure itself this is equivalent to setting the value of a particular node and removing all the edges between that node and its parents. There is an equivalent notion on the distribution itself which can be computed analytically.

2.3. Causal Fairness

Causal fairness notions (Kusner etÂ al., 2017; Kilbertus etÂ al., 2017) consider the dependence between a set of protected attributes Pğ‘ƒP and a set of outcome decisions Oğ‘‚O. Protected attributes are those which are considered sensitive and unactionable. For example, race and gender are considered unactionable attributes in highly sensitive tasks such as college admissions and loan applications. The outcome attribute Oğ‘‚O is the objective to predict given the other attributes.

Here, we focus on justifiable fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019) which considers additional admissible attributes. These attributes are considered actionable for decision making despite their possible causal links to protected attributes.

We begin by first introducing Kğ¾K fairness and then using that to derive the notion of justifiable fairness.

Definition 0 (K-fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019)).

Given the disjoint set of attributes ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}, protected attributes Pğ‘ƒP, and outcome attribute Oğ‘‚O we say that a mechanism â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} is Kğ¾K-fair with respect to

Pğ‘ƒP if for any context K=kğ¾ğ‘˜K=k and every outcome O=oğ‘‚ğ‘œO=o and every PiâˆˆPsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘ƒP_{i}\in P the following holds:

Pâ€‹[O=o|dâ€‹oâ€‹(Pi=0),dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k)]=Pâ€‹[O=o|dâ€‹oâ€‹(Pi=1),dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k)]ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ‘‚conditionalğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–0ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ¾ğ‘˜ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ‘‚conditionalğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–1ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ¾ğ‘˜P[O=o|do(P_{i}=0),do(K=k)]=P[O=o|do(P_{i}=1),do(K=k)]

That is, conditioned on the intervention on the attributes in Kğ¾K, the value of the protected attribute (Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}) should not affect the final outcome (O=oğ‘‚ğ‘œO=o).

K-fairness is usually defined with respect to the outcome of some algorithm such as a classifier but as most pre-processing techniques do, we will make the â€œreasonable classifierâ€ assumption, where the conditional probability of classification is close to that same conditional probability of the training label in the training set. Therefore, we will use the outcome of a classifier and the training label interchangeably here.

Definition 0 (Justifiable Fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019)).

Let ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} be the set of all attributes, let PâŠ‚ğ’œğ‘ƒğ’œP\subset{\mathcal{A}} be a set of protected attributes, let AâŠ‚ğ’œâˆ–Pğ´ğ’œğ‘ƒA\subset{\mathcal{A}}\setminus P be a set of admissible attributes, and let Oâˆˆğ’œâˆ–(PâˆªA)ğ‘‚ğ’œğ‘ƒğ´O\in{\mathcal{A}}\setminus(P\cup A) be an outcome attribute. A mechanism â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} is justifiably fair if it is Kğ¾K-fair with respect to all supersets KâŠ‡Ağ´ğ¾K\supseteq A.

Prior work (Salimi etÂ al., 2019) notes that, for a directed causal graph ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} over a probability distribution, if all directed paths from a protected attribute to the outcome attribute pass through at least one admissible attribute, then that probability distribution is justifiably fair.

Theorem 14 ((Salimi etÂ al., 2019)).

If all paths in a causal directed acyclic graph ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} going from protected attributes to outcome attributes go through at least one admissible variable then ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathcal{G}} is justifiably fair. If the probability distribution is faithful to the causal DAG, then the converse also holds.

While this is true for data that is faithful to a causal DAG, we will show in the sequel (PropositionÂ 3) that it is also true for data that is Markov compatible with that same graphical structure.

3. A Framework for the Generation of Fair and DP Synthetic Data

All of our mechanisms can be seen as imposing a distribution represented in the created Bayes net onto a particular dataset. This does not inherently preserve any causal structure nor impose any causal structure on the dataset it merely preserves a chosen set of measured statistics. In our setting, this is required as it is known that no private mechanism can preserve all possible statistics on a dataset (Dinur and Nissim, 2003) but instead, it must choose to preserve a subset of them and, even then, noise has to be infused into that subset.

3.1. Model For a Fair Marginals-MST

We now detail the model for a fair Marginals-MST, relate it to the synthetic data sampled in the second step (FigureÂ 1), and define the main problem at the center of our model.

Causal interpretation. Previous work on justifiable fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019) satisfies justifiable fairness by changing the underlying distribution to make attributes that could be causally linked to instead be independent. Fundamentally, this repair mechanism imposes independence between attributes and does not impose new casual structures. Similarly, our work can be seen as imposing an entire distribution onto a particular dataset. We generate distributions with independence properties that ensure the independence between the protected and outcome attributes when conditioned on the admissible attributes. We do not impose any given causal structures. Instead, we create data with a specific distribution from which no causality between protected and outcome attributes can be inferred.

Fairness of a Marginals-MST. We can adapt the notion of interventional fairness to Marginals-MST. As a first step, we need to bridge the gap between an undirected Marginals-MSTÂ and DefinitionÂ 12 that assumes a DAG. Here, we consider the option of multiple outcomes rather than a single outcome attribute. This generalization is very practical for the synthetic data generation scenario, as we explain in the discussion in SectionÂ 3.2.

Proposition 0.

Let Dğ·D be a database over the attribute set ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}, let P,A,OâŠ†ğ’œğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‚ğ’œP,A,O\subseteq{\mathcal{A}} be disjoint sets representing the protected, admissible and outcome attributes respectively, and let Tğ‘‡T be a directed Marginals-MSTÂ over ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}. If all directed paths in Tğ‘‡T going from any attribute in Pğ‘ƒP to any outcome attribute in Oğ‘‚O go through at least one attribute in Ağ´A, then the distribution of Tğ‘‡T is justifiably fair.

This proposition leads to the definition of a fair Marginals-MSTÂ Tğ‘‡T as one for which any directed Marginals-MSTÂ derived by directing the edges of Tğ‘‡T satisfies the premise in PropositionÂ 1.

Definition 0 (Fair Marginals-MST).

Given a database Dğ·D over attributes ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}, and disjoint sets P,A,OâŠ†ğ’œğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‚ğ’œP,A,O\subseteq{\mathcal{A}} representing the protected, admissible and outcome attributes respectively, a Marginals-MST, Tğ‘‡T, whose node set is ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} is fair if in any directed Marginals-MSTÂ obtained by directing the edges of Tğ‘‡T, all directed paths in Tğ‘‡T going from any attribute in Pğ‘ƒP to any outcome attribute in Oğ‘‚OÂ go through at least one attribute in Ağ´A.

Example 3.

FigureÂ 2(b) shows an example of a fair Marginals-MST. The only path from the protected attribute (sex) goes through at least one admissible attribute (education). Regardless of any direction imposed on the edges, the path between the outcome and protected attribute remains blocked by an admissible attribute.

We define a fair Marginals-MSTÂ as a Marginals-MSTÂ that satisfies PropositionÂ 1, regardless of the imposed direction of edges. This ensures that a fair Marginals-MSTÂ represents a distribution that is justifiably fair regardless of the sampling order. Since a Marginals-MSTÂ is a tree, we get the acyclic property â€˜for freeâ€™ as there cannot be cycles in the tree, regardless of the direction of the edges.

From a fair Marginals-MSTÂ to fair synthetic data. We now show that, given a fair Marginals-MST, one can sample data which satisfies the property in DefinitionÂ 13 as well, so long as the sampling approach preserves the distribution of the fair Marginals-MST.

Proposition 0.

Any synthetic database whose distribution is Markov Compatible (EquationÂ 4) with a directed fair Marginals-MSTÂ satisfies Justifiable Fairness (DefinitionÂ 13).

Intuitively, this proposition states that it is sufficient to find a fair Marginals-MSTÂ to ensure that the data derived from it is justifiably fair, as long as the sampling method is faithful to the distribution described by the fair tree. This is inherently true for any sampling method that preserves the distribution of a Bayes net (EquationÂ 3) such as the MSTÂ (McKenna etÂ al., 2021) and PrivBayesÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2014) sampling steps.

3.2. Problem Definition and Intractability

We have adapted the notion of interventional fairness to Marginals-MSTÂ and have further determined that it is sufficient to consider the fairness of the Marginals-MSTÂ to know that a synthetic database that is generated by a faithful sampling process will be fair. We can now define FDPSynthÂ (Fair DP Synthetic Data Generation) as the problem at the heart of PreFair.

Definition 0 (The FDPSynthÂ Problem).

Let Dğ·D be a database with attribute set ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}, a set of protected, admissible, and outcome attributes P,A,OâŠ†ğ’œğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‚ğ’œP,A,O\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}, such that P,A,Oğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‚P,A,O are non-empty and pairwise disjoint. Let G=(V,E,w)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘¤G=(V,E,w) be a graph encoding the mutual information between every pair of attributes in ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}, where V=ğ’œğ‘‰ğ’œV={\mathcal{A}} is the set of nodes, E=VÃ—Vğ¸ğ‘‰ğ‘‰E=V\times V is the set of edges, and w:VÃ—Vâ†’â„+âˆª{0}:ğ‘¤â†’ğ‘‰ğ‘‰superscriptâ„0w:V\times V\to\mathbb{R}^{+}\cup\{0\} is a weight function for pairs of nodes that denotes the mutual information between every pair of attributes in Dğ·D, wâ€‹(A1,A2)=0ğ‘¤subscriptğ´1subscriptğ´20w(A_{1},A_{2})=0 iff (A1,A2)âˆ‰Esubscriptğ´1subscriptğ´2ğ¸(A_{1},A_{2})\not\in E and the mutual information between A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} and A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} is 00. The FDPSynthÂ problem is to find a fair MST that maximizes the pairwise mutual information between the attributes in ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} while satisfying RDP for a given privacy parameter ÏğœŒ\rho.

Example 4.

Reconsider 1, where the protected attribute is sex, the admissible attributes are education, marital-status and the outcome attribute is income. We assume that there is a graph where the edges represent the mutual information between these attributes in the private database. The FDPSynthÂ problem is to generate a fair Marginals-MSTÂ that maximizes the pairwise mutual information between the attributes while satisfying RDP for a given ÏğœŒ\rho.

We next give a simple existence claim, which will be implicitly used by our solutions (SectionÂ 4) to find a fair Marginals-MST.

Proposition 0.

For any instance of the FDPSynthÂ problem, there exists a solution.

The need for multiple outcomes. Previous work on justifiable fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019) assumes that the database contains a single outcome attribute. However, in the context of generating private synthetic data this assumption is restrictive. In the non-private setting several different synthetic data sets can be constructed for individual tasks with different outcomes. In the private setting due to TheoremÂ 5 each release of privacy protected data comes at the cost of additional privacy leakage. As a result, it is more efficient to release a single set of synthetic data which considers multiple outcomes.

Example 5.

Reconsider FigureÂ 2(b) with the attribute relation as a second outcome. This simulates the case where the datatset needs to be used for two independent prediction tasks. In the first prediction task, income is to be predicted and in the second task relation status is to be predicted. Since both relation and income are to be predicted they should both be dependent on the admissible attributes and not the protected attribute (sex).

NP-hardness of FDPSynth. Here, we show that FDPSynthÂ is intractable. We first define the decision version of the FDPSynthÂ problem without the RDP requirement. We show that, even in the absence of the RDP requirement, the decision problem is NP-hard. In the presence of private noise every instance of the problem must have non-zero probability, therefore, the addition of privacy still allows for the graph instances that are shown in the proof.

Definition 0 (Decision version of FDPSynth).

Let Dğ·D be a database with attribute set ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}, a set of protected, admissible, and outcome attributes P,A,OâŠ†ğ’œğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‚ğ’œP,A,O\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}, such that P,A,Oğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‚P,A,O are non-empty and pairwise disjoint, and let kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}. In order to connect the problem on an abstract graph to a database, we note that there always exists a database where the mutual information between attributes results in the structures of the assignment gadget and the 3-way OR gadget.

Lemma 0.

There exists a database Dğ·D whose attributes have the mutual information relationship that results in the graph of FigureÂ 5.

4. Computing a Fair Marginals-MST

Here we propose both an exponential time optimal solution as well as a linear time greedy algorithm. It is important to note when designing each of these mechanisms, we first designed a non-private solution to the fair Marginals-MSTÂ problem then adapt them to satisfy RDP. Even if an optimal non-private solution is adapted it does not ensure that the resulting private solution is also optimal.

4.1. Exponential Asymptotically Optimal Algorithm

Here we present an exponential time solution for finding the optimal tree. The non-private version of this solution acts similarly to Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm. We take in as input the set of measured 1-way marginals, and the RDP privacy parameter ÏğœŒ\rho. In addition, the mechanism takes as input the sets of admissible, protected, and outcome attributes. We estimate all of the 2-way marginals using Private-PGMÂ (McKenna etÂ al., 2019). From there in line 1 we measure the L1 error of each of the 2-way marginals (a sensitivity 1 estimate of the mutual information) using the Gaussian mechanism and set each edge weight to the error of its corresponding marginal. In line 1 we create a priority queue where we will store partial Marginals-MSTs which will be sorted by their current weight in ascending order. In lines 1- 1 we set the weight of each edge to be the maximum measurement minus the measurement for that pair. This ensures that the attribute pairs with the highest mutual information have the lowest weight and reduces the problem to that of finding the lowest weight tree. This way the partial tree with the lowest weight will always remain on the top of the queue. In order to seed the queue in line 1, we add the partial tree where no nodes are connected with weight 00. From there (lines 1-1) at each time step we take the top partial tree from the queue and add to the queue all the possible trees with one additional edge that does not violate PropositionÂ 1. We continue this process until the first complete Marginals-MSTÂ is on the top of the queue. Since the queue is sorted by weight and adding any edge only increases the weight, the first complete Marginals-MSTÂ to be found, by definition, must be the minimum weight tree.

Example 6.

Consider the graph in FigureÂ 6 on the attributes of the Adult dataset. The magenta dashed-dotted edges show the output of Exponential-PreFairÂ in the absence of privacy noise. Exponential-PreFairÂ iterates through all permutations of partial Marginals-MSTs, checking those with high edge weights. The result (in the absence of noise) is the optimal Marginals-MSTÂ with a total weight of 30.

Correctness and optimality condition. We now detail the guarantees of Algorithm 1.

Lemma 0.

Algorithm 1 always terminates at line 1.

Proof.

Algorithm 1 iterates through all possible Marginals-MSTs as it considers all |ğ’œ||ğ’œ|superscriptğ’œğ’œ|{\mathcal{A}}|^{|{\mathcal{A}}|} spanning trees in lines 1 and 1, removing those which do not satisfy DefinitionÂ 2. Since a fair Marginals-MSTÂ always exists (see PropositionÂ 5), Algorithm 1 will find it and will terminate at line 1. âˆ

Proposition 0.

Given a private database Dğ·D over a set of attributes ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}, a set of admissible attributes AâŠ†ğ’œğ´ğ’œA\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}, a set of protected attributes PâŠ†ğ’œğ‘ƒğ’œP\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}, outcome attribute OâŠ†ğ’œğ‘‚ğ’œO\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}, measurements of 1-way marginals of ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} over Dğ·D, lâ€‹oâ€‹gğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”log, and a privacy parameter ÏğœŒ\rho, the following holds:

  1. (1)

    Algorithm 1 satisfies (Î±,Ïâ€‹Î±)âˆ’Râ€‹Dâ€‹Pğ›¼ğœŒğ›¼ğ‘…ğ·ğ‘ƒ(\alpha,\rho\alpha)-RDP for all Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1.

  2. (2)

    Algorithm 1 outputs a fair Marginals-MST.

While Algorithm 1 always outputs a fair Marginals-MSTÂ in all cases, it is only guaranteed to maximize the mutual information in the case without any privacy preserving noise. Adding privacy preserving noise to the optimal non-private mechanism does not always result in the optimal private mechanism.

Proposition 0.

In the absence of privacy preserving noise (as Ïâ†’âˆâ†’ğœŒ\rho\to\infty), Algorithm 1 outputs the fair Marginals-MSTÂ with maximum mutual information.

Complexity and privacy budget discussion. Algorithm 1 can be both slow and privacy intensive. First, there is an exponential number of possible spanning trees and, in the worst case, considering all of them is prohibitively expensive, resulting in the following time complexity.

Proposition 0.

The time complexity of Algorithm 1 is Oâ€‹(|ğ’œ||ğ’œ|âˆ’2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ’œğ’œ2O\left(|{\mathcal{A}}|^{|{\mathcal{A}}|-2}\right).

In terms of privacy budget, since there can be a possible exponential number of additions to the partial solution queue using the exponential mechanism at each time step is not practical. Instead, the mechanism measures all of the edges using the Gaussian mechanism and repeatedly uses those values when necessary. While better this still requires a larger split of the privacy budget than the greedy solution. Specifically, there are |ğ’œ|â€‹(|ğ’œ|âˆ’1)2ğ’œğ’œ12\frac{|{\mathcal{A}}|(|{\mathcal{A}}|-1)}{2} calls to the Gaussian mechanism in the algorithm. The repeated calls to the Gaussian mechanism requires that the privacy budget be split into smaller parts and as such results in higher noise in these measurements. This often leads to poor running time performance which we measure in SectionÂ 5.

4.2. Greedy Algorithm

We now introduce an alternative solution. We slightly change the selection step of MST (McKenna etÂ al., 2021) to only consider a subset of possible edges. This will always result in a fair Marginals-MSTÂ but may not be optimal in terms of mutual information. However, this solution runs in linear time with respect to the number of attributes. Furthermore, we show that this solution is optimal in certain special cases.

We can adapt the greedy selection step from the MST mechanism in order to generate a fair Marginals-MSTÂ by restricting the set of possible neighbors of outcome attributes. We simply restrict all the neighbors of outcome attributes to be either other outcome attributes or admissible attributes. This ensures that any path to the outcome attributes must pass through at least one admissible attribute. In practice, we employ the private Kruskalâ€™s algorithm (described in (McKenna etÂ al., 2021)) for finding a Marginals-MSTÂ but delete all the edges from outcome attributes to attributes that are neither outcomes nor admissible. This algorithm is shown in full in Algorithm 2. The blue line shows the modification to the original algorithm.

Algorithm 2 takes as input the database, the measured one-way marginals and the RDP privacy parameter ÏğœŒ\rho. Additionally, it takes in as input the set of admissible and protected variables. We then construct a Marginals-MSTÂ over a complete graph where the nodes are attributes and the edges represent 2-way marginals between attributes and their weights are low sensitivity estimates of the mutual information between the two. In order to get this estimation in line 2 we first estimate the 2-way marginals from the 1-way marginals using Private-PGM (McKenna etÂ al., 2019) then set each edgeâ€™s weights to be the L1 error of those estimates. We then do the private version of Kruskalâ€™s algorithm. In line 2, we first remove all the edges from outcome attributes to inadmissible attributes as adding any of these nodes would result in a violation of justifiable fairness. Then at each time step (lines 2-2) we select an edge to add to the partial maximum spanning tree from the set of edges that would connect two disjoint connected components. To maintain privacy, this selection is done via the exponential mechanism. After |ğ’œ|âˆ’1ğ’œ1|{\mathcal{A}}|-1 rounds of this process, the resulting edges will form a private estimation of a spanning tree over this graph. Once this MST is selected, the distribution measured directly using the Gaussian mechanism and are then used to generate the synthetic data.

Example 7.

Reconsider the graph in FigureÂ 6. The olive dashed edges show the output of Greedy-PreFairÂ in the absence of privacy noise. The mechanism greedily takes the highest weight edge so long as that edge is not between an attribute in Oğ‘‚O and an attribute not in OâˆªAğ‘‚ğ´O\cup A. In this example it starts by taking the edge between sex and age, then takes the edge between age and education followed by the edge between sex and relation and finally the edge between education and income. This results in a final edge weight of 242424 which is slightly less than the optimal 303030 however it still results in a fair Marginals-MST.

The proof that Algorithm 2 satisfies RDP is identical to the proof that the original MST algorithm satisfies DP (McKenna etÂ al., 2021). Furthermore, since Algorithm 2 only allows attributes in Oğ‘‚O to be adjacent to attributes in Ağ´A regardless of the sampling order each Oğ‘‚O is independent of all other nodes given the attributes in Ağ´A and, therefore, generates a fair Marginals-MST. As such, we get the following.

Proposition 0.

Given a private database Dğ·D, a set of admissible attributes Ağ´A, a set of protected attributes Pğ‘ƒP, outcome attribute Oğ‘‚O, measurements of 1-way marginals of the attributes of Dğ·D, lâ€‹oâ€‹gğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”log, and a privacy parameter ÏğœŒ\rho, the following holds:

  1. (1)

    Algorithm 2 satisfies (Î±,Ïâ€‹Î±)âˆ’Râ€‹Dâ€‹Pğ›¼ğœŒğ›¼ğ‘…ğ·ğ‘ƒ(\alpha,\rho\alpha)-RDP for all Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1.

  2. (2)

    Algorithm 2 outputs a fair Marginals-MST.

Optimality for the saturated case. Algorithm 2 is not optimal (in the absence of noise) in the general case as there are cases where the greedy solution results in a fair Marginals-MSTÂ with sub-optimal total mutual information. There is, however, a special case for which Algorithm 2 is optimal. When all attributes are either admissible protected or outcomes (i.e., Aâ€‹\cupdotâ€‹Oâ€‹\cupdotâ€‹P=ğ’œğ´\cupdotğ‘‚\cupdotğ‘ƒğ’œA\cupdot O\cupdot P={\mathcal{A}}), we say that the problem instance is saturated. The saturated case corresponds to the cases where the user has complete knowledge as to which attributes may or may not be used for decision making and there is no ambiguity among the attributes. In the saturated case, we note that in any fair Marginals-MST, all edges from outcome attributes must either come from other outcome attributes or admissible attributes.

Proposition 0.

Given a database Dğ·D over attributes ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}}, and disjoint sets P,A,OâŠ†ğ’œğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‚ğ’œP,A,O\subseteq{\mathcal{A}} representing the protected, admissible, and outcome attributes respectively, a Marginals-MSTÂ Tğ‘‡T whose node set is ğ’œğ’œ{\mathcal{A}} is fair if all the neighbors of nodes in the set Oğ‘‚O are in the set AâˆªOğ´ğ‘‚A\cup O. If the problem is saturated the converse is also true.

Thus, when the problem is saturated, finding the optimal fair Marginals-MSTÂ is equivalent to finding the MST on the subgraph containing no edges from attributes in Pğ‘ƒP to attributes not in Pğ‘ƒP or Ağ´A. Therefore, using a traditional MST algorithm such as Kruskalâ€™s algorithm (Kruskal, 1956) on this subgraph results in an optimal Marginals-MST. Thus, using Algorithm 2 yields an optimal fair Marginals-MST.

Complexity and privacy budget discussion. Algorithm 2 is efficient with respect to both privacy budget and computation time. Unlike Algorithm 1 which uses a quadratic number of calls to the Gaussian Mechanism, Algorithm 2 calls the exponential mechanism only a linear number of times. This results in significantly more privacy budget being allocated to each individual call of the exponential mechanism resulting in lower noise. Algorithm 2 also has a significantly improved run time. Since Algorithm 2 only selects |ğ’œ|âˆ’1ğ’œ1|{\mathcal{A}}|-1 edges using the exponential mechanism it only requires a linear time to run, in addition to the quadratic time for computing the 2-way marginals (lines 2,2). This is a dramatic improvement over Algorithm 1 which is exponential.

Proposition 0.

The time complexity of Algorithm 2 is Oâ€‹(|ğ’œ|2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ’œ2O\left(|{\mathcal{A}}|^{2}\right).

5. Experiments

We present experiments that evaluate the efficacy of the proposed mechanisms. In particular, we explore the following main questions.

  1. (1)

    Q1: What is the error overhead incurred by Algorithms 1 and 2 compared to MSTÂ (McKenna etÂ al., 2021)?

  2. (2)

    Q2: How effective are Algorithms 1 and 2 at reducing unfairness in downstream classification tasks?

  3. (3)

    Q3: What is the performance of Algorithms 1 and 2 compared to the baseline that does not consider fairness?

Implementation Details. We have implemented our system in Python 3.8 based on the existing MST approachÂ (McKenna etÂ al., 2021). All values shown are averaged over 101010 instances of synthetic data.

5.1. Experimental Setup

We next detail the settings of the experiments including the datasets used, the examined approaches, and the employed measures.

Datasets. We test our mechanisms on three datasets, each composed of a single table.

  • â€¢

    Adult (Bache and Lichman, 2013): This dataset contains 14 attributes and 48,843 tuples. It contains individualâ€™ census data. The objective is to predict if an individualâ€™s income is above or below 50K.

  • â€¢

    Compas (ProPublica, [n.d.]): This dataset contains 8 attributes and 6173 tuples. It contains the criminal history, jail and prison time, demographics and Compas risk scores for defendants from Broward County from 2013 and 2014. The objective is to predict if an individual will commit a crime again within 2 years.

  • â€¢

    Census KDD (Bache and Lichman, 2013; Tao etÂ al., 2021; Quy etÂ al., 2022): This dataset contains 41 attributes and 299,285 tuples. It contains information from the 1994 and 1995 Population Survey from the US census. The objective is to predict if an individualâ€™s income is above or below 50K.

To prepare the data for each task, we transformed categorical data into equivalent numerical data by mapping each domain value to a unique integer. Continuous data is instead treated as discrete categorical data with each unique value being its own category (see discussion on discretization in SectionÂ 7). We have listed the set of protected, admissible, and outcome variables in TableÂ 1.

Baselines and examined approaches. For baselines, we compare against the original versions of MST (McKenna etÂ al., 2021). For our mechanisms, we use adapted versions of each of these baselines, Exponential-PreFairÂ (Algorithm 1) and Greedy-PreFairÂ (Algorithm 2).

Each mechanism is used with 3 different settings of Ïµ=[0.1,1,10]italic-Ïµ0.1110\epsilon=[0.1,1,10].

We found the optimal RDP parameters and converted back to traditional DP using TheoremÂ 4. Each mechanism is set to generate a dataset of the same size as the original dataset. All measurements are done over 10 samples of synthetic data for each mechanism.

We generated learned models using Tensorflow (Abadi etÂ al., 2015) for MLP models and scikit-learn (Pedregosa etÂ al., 2011) for linear regression as well as random forests. Each model was trained using one set of synthetic data and was tested against the underlying true data.

Data quality. In order to measure the overall quality of the data, we consider the same set of metrics as past benchmarks (Tao etÂ al., 2021). Each of these metrics are intended to measure a different quality of the data that should be preserved in the synthetic data.

  1. (1)

    Individual Attribute Distribution: We measure the similarity of the 1-way marginals between the synthetic and original data. To do so, we measure the Total Variation Distance (TVD) between a vectorized version of the 1-way marginals for both the synthetic and original data. The value shown is the average of the total variation distances for each 1-way marginal. We show the distribution over 10 samples of synthetic data.

  2. (2)

    Pairwise Attribute Distribution: We extend the methodology of 1-way marginals to instead measure the distributions of 2-way marginals as well. As before we measure the TVD of the 2-way marginals vectors of the original and synthetic data and show the average over all 2-way marginals.

  3. (3)

    Pairwise Correlation Similarity: As inÂ (Tao etÂ al., 2021), we measure the Cramerâ€™s V with bias correction measure between each pair of attributes. Cramerâ€™s V, which lies in the range [0,1]01[0,1], is a measure of correlation between two attributes with higher values signifying a larger correlation. We measure the difference between the measures in the synthetic and original data and show the average of the differences across all pairs of attributes, a measure we call the average correlation difference (ACD).

  4. (4)

    Downstream Classification Accuracy: Here we use the synthetic data to train several classifiers and use it to classify the original data. We report the accuracy Tâ€‹P+Tâ€‹NTâ€‹P+Fâ€‹P+Fâ€‹N+Tâ€‹Nğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ¹ğ‘ƒğ¹ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘\frac{TP+TN}{TP+FP+FN+TN} for a model trained on each of the 10 output samples.

Fairness metrics. We also measure the impact that training on the fairness constrained synthetic data has on downstream classification fairness. For each of these measures, we trained a MLP, Random Forrest, and Linear Regression models on the synthetic data and measured commonly used empirical indicators of fairness.

In order to establish our results, we employ many of the same measures used in (Salimi etÂ al., 2019).

  1. (1)

    Demographic Parity (Kleinberg etÂ al., 2017; Dwork etÂ al., 2012): Demographic Parity measures the difference in the rate at which each class is classified as having an income of higher than 50K.

  2. (2)

    True Positive Rate Balance (Chouldechova, 2017; Simoiu etÂ al., 2017): This measures the overall rate of true positives across both the privileged and non-privileged group.

  3. (3)

    True Negative Rate Balance (Chouldechova, 2017; Hardt etÂ al., 2016): This measures the overall rate of true negatives across both the privileged and non-privileged group.

  4. (4)

    Conditional Measures (Corbett-Davies etÂ al., 2017): We measure the expected value of the above metrics conditioned on the admissible attributes. This more directly captures the notion of justifiable fairness as the admissible variables are directly allowed be used regardless of their discriminatory effects. However, discrimination within groups with identical admissible attributes is prohibited. This measures the discrimination within each group with identical admissible attributes. These measures are abbreviated as their non-conditional counterparts with an additional Cğ¶C prior.

5.2. Experimental Results

We first give an overview of all aspects of the results, using TableÂ 3, and then give an in-depth analysis of the quality and fairness results, using FiguresÂ 7 andÂ 8.

Overview of the performance Greedy-Marginals-MST. TableÂ 3 gives an overview of the experimental results for Greedy-PreFairÂ (Algorithm 2) compared to MST across all datasets with a singular privacy budget of Ïµ=1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon=1. Across all datasets, the cost of fairness is relatively low and does not significantly hinder accuracy.

In both the Adult and KDD datasets, Greedy-PreFairÂ incurs no more than a 2%percent22\% increase in error, on both 1-way and 2-way marginals, due to the additional fairness constraints. Greedy-PreFairÂ incurs a larger error on the Compas dataset, on the 2-way marginals, incurring an almost 20%percent2020\% increase in error compared to MST. This is a result of the greater inequities that exist in the Compas dataset. In order for PreFairÂ to satisfy the fairness constraint, the mechanism generates a distribution that has a greater deviation than the fairer datasets. Since each of the mechanisms only differ in how they measure the 2-way marginals this greater deviation is only represented in the 2-way marginals. This is similarly reflected in the downstream MLP accuracy as Greedy-PreFairÂ incurs a relatively small penalty in accuracy compared to MST for both the Adult and KDD datasets but incurs a larger penalty for the Compas dataset.

In terms of fairness metrics, Greedy-PreFairÂ yields better results on all of the fairness measures regardless of the dataset. Since Greedy-PreFairÂ ensures independence when conditioned on the admissible attributes the conditional fairness metrics are significantly reduced. This also impacts the non-conditional measures as they are also reduced albeit by a smaller amount. While all the measures improved by a similar percentage since both the adult and KDD datasets had little disparity originally, the overall change is less significant than the change in the Compas dataset, which has a significantly higher base rate of disparity. We show the significance of these changes in FigureÂ 8.

We have also measured the overall runtime for Greedy-PreFairÂ compared to MST. Greedy-PreFairÂ performs slightly better than MST in most cases and the improvement increases with the increase in the size of the dataset (TableÂ 3). This is a result of the greedy optimization where Greedy-PreFairÂ considers fewer options than MST for neighbors of outcome attributes. We measured the runtime of Exponential-PreFairÂ as well. Even on small datasets it takes 10 times longer than either MST or Greedy-PreFairÂ and is prohibitively expensive to run on a large dataset222Exponential-PreFairÂ has a significantly higher runtime overhead. As Exponential-PreFairÂ runs in exponential time we were only able to measure performance on the Adult and Compas datasets. In the low privacy regime (Ïµ=0.1italic-Ïµ0.1\epsilon=0.1), Exponential-PreFairÂ can take up to 10 times longer than MST, taking on average 1344 seconds to run. In larger datasets, this overhead becomes prohibitively expensive as it scales exponentially in the number of attributes..

Data quality. FigureÂ 7 shows a detailed breakdown of the quality measures across different privacy budgets and both Greedy and Exponential - PreFair. Greedy-PreFairÂ performs similarly to MST in all cases. In FigureÂ 7(a) we can see that in the worst case when Ïµ=0.1italic-Ïµ0.1\epsilon=0.1 Greedy-PreFairÂ has only a 1%percent11\% increase in error. In FigureÂ 7(b) we see that this increases to a 7%percent77\% increase in error across 2-way marginals when compared to MST. While Exponential-PreFairÂ (Algorithm 1) performed similarly to MST on 1-way marginals (FigureÂ 7(a)), it performed poorly on 2-way marginals (FigureÂ 7(b)). At Ïµ=0.1italic-Ïµ0.1\epsilon=0.1 Exponential-PreFairÂ sees a 7%percent77\% increase but when the privacy budget increases to Ïµ=10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon=10 that the increase in error is as large as 60%percent6060\%. Despite the additional optimization in choosing a Marginals-MST, Exponential-PreFairÂ invokes the Gaussian mechanism significantly more often than either MST or Greedy-PreFair. This results in less privacy budget for each invocation and thus more noise per measurement leading to more error.

In FigureÂ 7(c), the patterns are similar to the 2-way marginals. Greedy-PreFairÂ incurs a small 1%percent11\% increase in error when the Exponential-PreFairÂ sees a 56%percent5656\% increase in error at Ïµ=10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon=10. FigureÂ 7(d) shows the downstream classification accuracy of MLP models. The results on the Random Forrest models and linear regression models are largely similar and have been omitted from the figure. The difference in classification accuracy between MST and Greedy-PreFairÂ never exceeds 1%percent11\% even across all classifiers and privacy budgets. Exponential-PreFairÂ performs similarly in most cases but performs slightly worse than the baseline in the low privacy setting. When Ïµ=10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon=10, the difference between the accuracy of the MLP model trained on MST and Exponential-PreFairÂ data is 4%percent44\%.

Fairness metrics. FigureÂ 8 showcases the fairness measures in more detail for the Compas dataset. Every entry in the matrix shows the median results over 10 runs for a specific approach measured by a specific associational fairness metric, where lower numbers (denoted by lighter colors) indicate better fairness. Overall, our methods decrease observed unfairness regardless of the downstream classifier used and regardless of the privacy budget. The tradeoff comes in the quality of data. While the downstream classifiers remain fair regardless of the privacy budget the overall accuracy and quality of the data decreases with increased privacy. MST shows significant disparities in both conditional and unconditional measures (>0.15absent0.15>0.15). Generating data using either of the fair methods results in a significantly fairer downstream classifier. On average, the unconditional fairness metrics of Greedy-PreFairÂ are 45%percent4545\% of those seen with MST and the conditional fairness metrics are 20%percent2020\% of those seen with MST. This is expected, as our solutions ensures that there will be no correlation between sensitive attributes and outcome attributes when conditioned on the admissible attributes. This results in a reduction in the unconditional associational metrics while the conditioned metrics are more significantly reduced. Of the three classifiers tested, the linear regression model benefited the most from the fair synthetic data. On average, when using data from the fair mechanisms the linear regression model saw a decrease in unconditional fairness metrics to 35%percent3535\% of that observed when using the data from MST. The conditional fairness metrics dropped to 14%percent1414\% of what was observed when using data from MST.

6. Related Work

We give a detailed review of related works. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that proposes an approach for generating fair synthetic data while satisfying DP.

Differentially private data generation. By releasing synthetic data, one can release a large dataset that can be used for an unbounded amount of computation, all while preserving privacy. There are many methods for generating differentially private synthetic data (Chen etÂ al., 2020; Liu etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2014; AydÃ¶re etÂ al., 2021; Ge etÂ al., 2021; Jordon etÂ al., 2019; Hardt etÂ al., [n.d.]; Zhang etÂ al., 2021; Snoke and Slavkovic, 2018; Torkzadehmahani etÂ al., 2019; Rosenblatt etÂ al., 2020; Xie etÂ al., 2018; McKenna etÂ al., 2019, 2021) including methods that use low level marginals to approximate the data (McKenna etÂ al., 2021; Zhang etÂ al., 2014; McKenna etÂ al., 2019), and GAN based methods (Xie etÂ al., 2018; Rosenblatt etÂ al., 2020; Jordon etÂ al., 2019) among others. According to past work (Tao etÂ al., 2021) the marginals-based approaches such as MST (McKenna etÂ al., 2021), PrivBayes (Zhang etÂ al., 2014) and MWEM-PGM (McKenna etÂ al., 2019) tend to perform best in the private setting. Kamino (Ge etÂ al., 2021) also provides DP synthetic data generation with constraints, but focuses on denial constraints (Chomicki and Marcinkowski, 2005), rather than causality-based constraints.

Fair data generation. Many works have defined fairness in different ways. Our approach relies on justifiable fairness (Salimi etÂ al., 2019) which is a causal-based notion of fairness. Other works consider associational fairness measures based on some statistical measures relative to the protected attributes. Additionally, conditional associational fairness measures (Corbett-Davies etÂ al., 2017) have been proposed. These measures consider a set of attributes to be conditioned on. Likewise, there have been approaches for generating non-private fair synthetic data (Xu etÂ al., 2019; van Breugel etÂ al., 2021) GAN based approaches such as FairGAN (Xu etÂ al., 2019) have been used to generate data that satisfies these associational measures. While GAN-based approaches work well in the non-private setting, they have been shown to perform poorly in the private setting (Tao etÂ al., 2021).

7. Extensions of PreFair

Here we detail several possible extensions. These include expanding the techniques used in PreFairÂ to other private synthetic data mechanisms such as PrivBayes (Zhang etÂ al., 2014) as well as extending the techniques shown here to numerical and continuous data.

Other private data generation mechanisms. While PreFairÂ relied on MSTÂ (McKenna etÂ al., 2021), all of our propositions in SectionÂ 3 apply to any Bayes network for synthetic data generation which samples from a generated graphical model, both private and non-private. This applies to private mechanisms beyond MST. For instance, both PrivBayesÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2014) and MWEM-PGM (McKenna etÂ al., 2019) generate a graphical model and sample from it directly. To adapt these mechanisms, one only needs to change the selection step, where the graphical model is generated. The selection step must be changed to either consider only admissible attributes as neighbors of outcome attributes (Algorithm 2) or find the optimal fair Marginals-MSTÂ (Algorithm 1).

Additional data types. MST (McKenna etÂ al., 2021) along with other marginal approaches takes discrete data as input. These techniques can handle numeric attributes by first using a discretization step to map the numeric domain into a discrete domain. This can be done using using a data independent method or a private subroutine such as PrivTree (Zhang etÂ al., 2016). Previous work (Tao etÂ al., 2021) has shown that a data dependent discretization can lead to a large increase in performance overall, particularly in large datasets. In these cases, there is a tradeoff between the expressiveness and performance of the dataset. A fine-grained discretization is more expressive but leads to higher noise while coarse-grained discretization loses some information but can result in a lower overall error. In SectionÂ 5, we evaluate PreFairÂ on several datasets containing mostly categorical data and discretize numerical attributes with single-value buckets. In future work, it would be intriguing to assess the impact of different discretization approaches on the quality and performance of our system.

Additional fairness definitions. Justifiable fairness is only one of many different fairness definitions, both causal and non-causal (Kleinberg etÂ al., 2017; Dwork etÂ al., 2012; Chouldechova, 2017; Simoiu etÂ al., 2017; Hardt etÂ al., 2016; Corbett-Davies etÂ al., 2017). While we show in SectionÂ 5 that satisfying justifiable fairness also improves additional fairness metrics, there are no guarantees that they are satisfied. As such we leave it to future work to generate private synthetic data that also satisfies additional fairness definitions. Likewise, incorporating integrity constraints in PreFairÂ is an important future work that will allow the generated data to have other desired properties. While past work (Ge etÂ al., 2021) has incorporated such constraints into private synthetic data, those solutions do not consider fairness.

8. Conclusion

We have presented PreFair, a system for generating justifiably fair synthetic data under differential privacy. Our approach relies on a state-of-the-art DP data generation system, as well as the definition of justifiable fairness. We have formally defined the problem of generating fair synthetic data that preserves DP and showed that it is NP-hard. Bearing this in mind, we devised two algorithms that guarantee fairness and DP, and have further extended our greedy approach to other DP synthetic data generation systems. Additionally, we have formulated a requirement for the sampling approach to ensure that the generated data comply with the fairness desideratum. We have experimentally shown that our approach provides significant improvements in the fairness of the data while incurring low overhead in terms of faithfulness to the private data.

A.1. Proofs for Section 3

Proof of PropositionÂ 1.

The proof is largely the same as that in past work (Salimi etÂ al., 2019). Note that for any choice of KâŠ‡Ağ´ğ¾K\supseteq A, if all the directed paths go through at least one attribute in Kğ¾K then intervening on Kğ¾K, that is dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k)ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ¾ğ‘˜do(K=k) then at least one of the edges in the path will always be severed. This will separate all nodes in Oğ‘‚O from those in Pğ‘ƒP and thus any further intervention on Pğ‘ƒP cannot influence the distribution of Oğ‘‚O. âˆ

Proof of PropositionÂ 3.

Here, we show that given a set KâŠ‡Ağ´ğ¾K\supseteq A that the probability of the outcome is dependent only on the intervention on Kğ¾K and is the same regardless of the value of pğ‘p. We rely on a fact from (Pearl, 1995) namely the following equivalence on the do operator.

(5) Pâ€‹(O=o|dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k),dâ€‹oâ€‹(P=p))=Pâ€‹(O=o|dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k))if(OâŸ‚âŸ‚P|K)Pâ€‹KÂ¯\begin{split}P(O=o|do(K=k),do(P=p))=P(O=o|do(K=k))\\ \text{if}(O\perp\!\!\!\perp P|K)_{\overline{PK}}\end{split}

Where Pâ€‹KÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ƒğ¾\overline{PK} denotes the distribution derived by removing all edges pointing to attributes in Pğ‘ƒP and Kğ¾K.

This will allow us to show that the outcome is independent of any intervention on Pğ‘ƒP once we have already intervened on Kğ¾K,i.e., applying the dâ€‹oğ‘‘ğ‘œdo operator on Pğ‘ƒP does not change the probability. In particular, we will be able to show that Pâ€‹[O=o|dâ€‹oâ€‹(Pi=0),dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k)]=Pâ€‹[O=o|dâ€‹oâ€‹(Pi=1),dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k)]=Pâ€‹[O=o|dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k)]ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ‘‚conditionalğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–0ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ¾ğ‘˜ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ‘‚conditionalğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–1ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ¾ğ‘˜ğ‘ƒdelimited-[]ğ‘‚conditionalğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘œğ¾ğ‘˜P[O=o|do(P_{i}=0),do(K=k)]=P[O=o|do(P_{i}=1),do(K=k)]=P[O=o|do(K=k)], which is the definition of K-fairness.

We also highly rely on the concept of d-separation a notion that can be directly observed on the graph. We say two attributes Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY are d-connected (and thus not d-separated) conditioned on a set of attributes Zğ‘Z if any of the following hold.

  • â€¢

    There exists an undirected path from Xğ‘‹X to Yğ‘ŒY that is not blocked by Zğ‘Z

  • â€¢

    There exists an undirected path from Xğ‘‹X to Yğ‘ŒY that is not blocked by a collider aâˆ‰Zğ‘ğ‘a\notin Z

Where a collider is an attribute along the undirected path where both edges in the path are directed towards that attribute.

Let Kğ¾K be any superset of Ağ´A which shares no elements with Pğ‘ƒP. Note that in any directed Marginals-MSTthere is exactly one undirected path between any attribute in Pğ‘ƒP and any attribute in Oğ‘‚O. Likewise this path is always blocked by at least one attribute in Kğ¾K.

Therefore the path from the attribute in Pğ‘ƒP to an attribute in Oğ‘‚O must have one of the structures shown in FigureÂ 9 where Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY denote arbitrary sets of nodes along the path with arbitrary directed edges between them. Double edges denote an edge that can be in any arbitrary direction. Î Î \Pi denotes an attribute in Pğ‘ƒP, Î©Î©\Omega denotes an attribute in Oğ‘‚O and Î±ğ›¼\alpha denotes an attribute in Ağ´A. Note that the path must either pass through Î±ğ›¼\alpha (the first case), have edges that go to Î±ğ›¼\alpha (the second case) or have edges that originate from Î±ğ›¼\alpha (the third case).

In the graph Pâ€‹KÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ƒğ¾\overline{PK} where all edges going into attributes in Pğ‘ƒP and Kğ¾K are removed each of these cases introduces a d-separation between Î©Î©\Omega and Î Î \Pi when conditioned on Kğ¾K. In the first case, the edge going into Î±ğ›¼\alpha is removed and as such the path is severed. In the second case, both edges going to Î±ğ›¼\alpha are removed and the path is severed. In the third case, no edges are severed but conditioning on Î±ğ›¼\alpha d-separates Î Î \Pi and Î©Î©\Omega since it blocks the path and is not a collider.

Since the dataset is Markov compatible with the graph then the d-separation of Î©Î©\Omega and Î Î \Pi imply that the two are independent when conditioned on Î±ğ›¼\alpha. Since they are conditionally independent we can use EquationÂ 5 to show that Pâ€‹(O=o|dâ€‹oâ€‹(K=k),dâ€‹oâ€‹(P=p))ğ‘ƒğ‘‚conditionalğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘œğ¾ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘ƒğ‘P(O=o|do(K=k),do(P=p)) is the same regardless of the intervention on Pğ‘ƒP. Therefore, the distribution satisfies K-fairness. Likewise since Kğ¾K could be an arbitrary superset of Ağ´A then the distribution also satisfies justifiable fairness. âˆ

Taking these edges both maximizes the weight as it takes all the 2 weight edges and only one 1 weight edge from either 2-way or gadget. This also ensures that the resulting Marginals-MSTÂ is fair since each outcome in the 3-way OR gadget has paths all blocked by admissible attributes. In each case for any maximal spanning tree at most one path from the literals to the outcome may be blocked since only one of the weigh 1 edges can be taken.

âˆ

Proof of LemmaÂ 8.

Here we first show that we can create a set of random variables A,B,C,Dğ´ğµğ¶ğ·A,B,C,D which results in the graph where B,C,Dğµğ¶ğ·B,C,D all have arbitrary mutual information with Ağ´A and there is no mutual information between any other pair of variables. From there we demonstrate that we can extend this construction to an arbitrary number of variables each with their arbitrary weight. We argue that this construction is sufficient to be able to construct a graph with the structure of the 3-way OR gadget.

Proof of PropositionÂ 5 (2).

Proof of PropositionÂ 6.

Assume that all the neighbors of nodes in Oğ‘‚O are in OâˆªAğ‘‚ğ´O\cup A. Any path from a node in Pğ‘ƒP to a node in oâˆˆOğ‘œğ‘‚o\in O must pass through at least one of oğ‘œoâ€™s neighbors. If that neighbor is in Ağ´A then the path is blocked by an admissible attribute therefore satisfying PropositionÂ 1. If that neighbor was in Oğ‘‚O then the path must also go through one of its neighbors which must be in OâˆªAğ‘‚ğ´O\cup A. Since only nodes in Ağ´A are allowed to have edges to nodes outside of OâˆªAğ‘‚ğ´O\cup A then the path must go through at least one of these nodes therefore blocking the path and satisfying PropositionÂ 1.

To prove the converse we use a proof by contradiction. Since xğ‘¥x is in Pğ‘ƒP and is neighbor of oğ‘œo then there exists a direction of edges (xğ‘¥x-Â¿oğ‘œo) such that oğ‘œo is directly dependent on xğ‘¥x resulting in a violation of DefinitionÂ 2.
